title: A Risky Business? The Politics of Knowledge Transfer in Public Health
abstractText:
This project will explore: how individuals involved in developing UK public health policies are experiencing efforts to increase/improve the use of evidence (eg what policymakers think about ‘research impact’ agendas and guidelines for increasing/improving the use of evidence in policy); and what role third sector and commercial organisations play in mediating/translating public health knowledge. 

The aims are: to unpack some of the assumptions underlying contemporary debates about ‘evidence-based policy’ and ‘research impact’; to explore the interactions of values, politics and evidence; and to further develop an ideational framework for understanding relationships between research and policy. 

In practical terms, the intention is to collaborate with potential research users to develop sector-specific recommendations for using public health research to improve policies (rather than simply trying to increase the flow of public health evidence into policy). 

To achieve this, the project combines five methodological approaches: literature reviews; assessing policy tools/guidance designed to improve the use of public health evidence in policy; a series of ethnographic placements in relevant third sector organisations; in-depth interviews with politicians and individuals working in relevant roles in the civil service, commercial sector and third sector; and an online Delphi survey of these sectors.
